metadata.title: Geometrical Constructions
metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.description: Constructing triangles using compass and ruler ‚Äî angle bisectors, perpendicular bisectors, incentre, circumcentre

preAssessment.question: A line that divides an angle into two equal parts is called _____.
The point where the three angle bisectors of a triangle meet is called _____.
The point where the three perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle meet is called _____.
To construct a triangle, we need at least _____.
In a right-angled triangle construction, the hypotenuse is _____.

concepts.title: Angle Bisector and Perpendicular Bisector
concepts.content: An angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts. A perpendicular bisector of a line segment divides it into two equal parts at 90¬∞. Both are constructed using a compass and ruler. Verify that the bisector is correct by checking equal angles or equal lengths.

examples.text: Ray BM bisects ‚à†ABC: m‚à†ABM = m‚à†MBC
Perpendicular bisector of PS: cuts PS at M with PM=SM and ‚à†CMP=90¬∞
Use compass to draw arcs from both ends of segment
Verify: check equal halves with ruler or divider

keyPoints: Angle bisector: divides angle into two equal angles
Perpendicular bisector: divides segment into two equal parts at 90¬∞
Use compass width greater than half the segment length
Draw arcs from both endpoints; join intersection points
Verify using a protractor or ruler
concepts.funFact: üèõÔ∏è Ancient Greek geometers constructed perfect bisectors using only compass and straightedge ‚Äî no measuring needed!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 1: Angle Bisector and Perpendicular Bisector

concepts.title: Incentre of a Triangle
concepts.content: The three angle bisectors of a triangle are concurrent (meet at one point) called the incentre (I). The incentre is always inside the triangle. The distances from the incentre to all three sides are equal ‚Äî this equal distance is the radius of the inscribed circle.

examples.text: Draw ‚ñ≥PQR, bisect all three angles ‚Äî they meet at point I (incentre)
IA = IB = IC (equal perpendicular distances to sides)
A circle centred at I and touching all three sides can be drawn
Incentre is always inside the triangle for any type of triangle

keyPoints: Three angle bisectors meet at the incentre I
Incentre is always inside the triangle
Distance from I to all three sides is equal
A circle with centre I touches all three sides (inscribed circle)
Shown by the letter I
concepts.funFact: üéØ The incentre is equidistant from all three sides ‚Äî it's the centre of the largest circle that fits inside the triangle!

concepts.title: Circumcentre of a Triangle
concepts.content: The three perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle are concurrent, meeting at the circumcentre (C). CX = CY = CZ (equidistant from all vertices). For acute triangles, C is inside; for obtuse triangles, C is outside; for right triangles, C is on the hypotenuse.

examples.text: Perpendicular bisectors of PQ, QR, PR meet at circumcentre C
CX = CY = CZ (equal distance to all vertices)
A circle centred at C passing through all 3 vertices
Acute: C inside; Obtuse: C outside; Right: C on hypotenuse

keyPoints: Perpendicular bisectors of all three sides meet at circumcentre C
Circumcentre is equidistant from all three vertices
Circles centred at C passes through all vertices (circumscribed circle)
Position depends on triangle type: inside/outside/on hypotenuse
Shown by the letter C
concepts.funFact: üåç When you find the circumcentre of a triangle formed by three cities, you find the point equidistant from all three ‚Äî useful for placing a central facility!

concepts.title: Constructing Triangles ‚Äî SSS, SAS, ASA
concepts.content: To construct a unique triangle, you need three measurements. Triangles can be constructed when given: SSS (three sides), SAS (two sides and included angle), ASA (two angles and included side), RHS (right angle, hypotenuse, one side). Use compass and ruler following the rough figure.

examples.text: SSS: ‚ñ≥XYZ with XY=5cm, YZ=7cm, XZ=5cm (draw base, use compass for other sides)
SAS: ‚ñ≥PQR with PQ=5cm, ‚à†Q=50¬∞, QR=5cm (draw base, measure angle, draw second side)
ASA: ‚ñ≥MAN with ‚à†A=90¬∞, MA=3.2cm, ‚à†M=55¬∞
RHS: right angle, hypotenuse, one side ‚Äî draw right angle first

keyPoints: Three measurements needed for a unique triangle
SSS: three sides; SAS: two sides + included angle
ASA: two angles + included side; RHS: right angle + hypotenuse + side
Draw a rough figure first
Use compass for lengths and protractor for angles
concepts.funFact: üèóÔ∏è Engineers use triangle constructions for bridges and trusses ‚Äî triangles are the strongest shape for structures!

concepts.title: Constructing Isosceles and Right-angled Triangles
concepts.content: Isosceles triangle: two equal sides. To construct, draw the base, then use compass to mark equal lengths from both ends. Right-angled triangle: one 90¬∞ angle. Use set-square or construct perpendicular. RHS condition: given hypotenuse and one side, the third side is found using Pythagoras.

examples.text: Isosceles ‚ñ≥: base = 5cm, equal sides = 6cm each
Right-angled ‚ñ≥MAT: ‚à†MAT=90¬∞, MA=4cm, AT=3cm
RHS: hypotenuse=10cm, one leg=6cm ‚Üí third side=8cm
Verify Pythagoras: 6¬≤+8¬≤=100=10¬≤ ‚úì

keyPoints: Isosceles: two equal sides, draw using compass arcs
Right-angled: one 90¬∞ angle, use set-square or protractor
RHS: Right angle, Hypotenuse, Side
Can construct even when two angles sum to 90¬∞
Verify constructions by measuring all sides and angles
concepts.funFact: üî∫ The Great Pyramid of Egypt has isosceles triangular faces ‚Äî built with remarkable geometric precision over 4000 years ago!

test.question: The point where the three angle bisectors of a triangle meet is called _____.
test.explanation: The angle bisectors of a triangle are concurrent at the incentre (I), which is always inside the triangle.

test.question: The circumcentre is equidistant from _____.
test.explanation: The circumcentre C is equidistant from all three vertices: CX = CY = CZ.

test.question: The incentre is always _____.
options: At the midpoint of the longest side
test.explanation: The incentre (intersection of angle bisectors) is always inside the triangle for any triangle.

test.question: The perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle are concurrent at the _____.
test.explanation: The three perpendicular bisectors meet at the circumcentre C.

test.question: To construct a unique triangle, you need a minimum of _____ measurements.
test.explanation: Three measurements (sides and/or angles in the right combination) are needed to uniquely determine a triangle.

test.question: In ‚ñ≥MAT with ‚à†MAT=90¬∞, MA=4cm and AT=3cm, what is the hypotenuse MT?
test.explanation: MT¬≤ = MA¬≤ + AT¬≤ = 16+9 = 25. MT = 5 cm. (3-4-5 right triangle)

test.question: Which gives the construction method 'SSS'?
options: Two sides and one angle given
Two angles and one side given
test.explanation: SSS stands for Side-Side-Side: all three sides are given for the triangle construction.

test.question: For an obtuse-angled triangle, the circumcentre lies _____.
test.explanation: For an obtuse triangle, the circumcentre lies outside the triangle; for acute, inside; for right-angled, on the hypotenuse.

test.question: What is the angle bisector of ‚à†ABC?
options: Ray that divides ‚à†ABC into two equal angles
Line through the midpoint of AC
test.explanation: The angle bisector of ‚à†ABC divides it into two equal angles: m‚à†ABM = m‚à†MBC

test.question: From the incentre I of a triangle, IA = IB = IC where A, B, C are the feet of perpendiculars. This means _____.
options: Incentre is equidistant from all three sides
Incentre is equidistant from all three vertices
test.explanation: IA, IB, IC are perpendicular distances from I to the three sides. They are equal, meaning I is equidistant from all sides.

keyConcepts: Angle bisector: divides angle into two equal parts
Perpendicular bisector: divides segment into equal halves at 90¬∞
Incentre (I): intersection of three angle bisectors, always inside triangle, equidistant from all sides
Circumcentre (C): intersection of three perpendicular bisectors, equidistant from all vertices
Triangle construction: need 3 measurements (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS)
Circumcentre: inside for acute, outside for obtuse, on hypotenuse for right triangle
commonMisconceptions: Incentre is equidistant from vertices ‚Äî FALSE, it's equidistant from SIDES
Circumcentre is always inside ‚Äî FALSE, it can be outside (obtuse triangles)
You can construct a triangle with just 2 measurements ‚Äî FALSE, need 3
Angle bisector and perpendicular bisector are the same ‚Äî FALSE, completely different
realWorldExamples: Bridge trusses use triangular constructions for strength
Finding incentre: centre of largest circle fitting inside a triangular park
Finding circumcentre: equidistant point from three cities
Isosceles triangle: rooftops and architectural gables
Right-angled triangle: set squares, ramps, stairs

formulas.formula: Incentre: equidistant from all three sides
formulas.explanation: IA = IB = IC (perpendicular distances to sides)

formulas.formula: Circumcentre: equidistant from all three vertices
